title: Opinion : Why there is no such thing as a  natural  disaster
message:
Charting a safer, more resilient course means first acknowledging that there is no such thing as a “natural disaster.” The word “natural” implies these events are entirely out of our control, thereby absolving us of the responsibility to prepare and reduce risk from natural hazards.
When we destroy and degrade much of the natural world, we make communities more vulnerable to disasters.
Without the storage capacity these natural systems provide, the risk of devastating floods and landslides increases.

title: Tropical storm Debby expected to intensify into hurricane , poses threat to Florida gulf coast
message:
Tropical Storm Debby is anticipated to intensify into a hurricane before reaching the Big Bend area of Florida's Gulf Coast by Monday afternoon, according to the US National Hurricane Center (NHC).
The NHC has cautioned about the potential for life-threatening storm surges.As of Sunday evening, Debby had sustained winds of 70 mph (112 km/h), just shy of hurricane status.
The storm is expected to bring storm surges of up to 10 feet (3 meters) in certain areas.As it slowly progresses northward throughout the week, Debby may bring "potentially historic rainfall" of 10 to 20 inches (25 to 50 cm) and devastating flooding to Georgia and South Carolina , with some local areas possibly receiving up to 30 inches of rain by Friday morning.Jamie Rhome, the deputy director of the hurricane centre, emphasised that the slow-moving nature of the storm will result in historic rainfall amounts and catastrophic flooding.
DeSantis also said that more than 17,000 linemen and other electric workers are ready to restore power if needed.
The governors of Georgia and South Carolina have also declared states of emergency in anticipation of the storm.

title: Debby Intensifies Into Hurricane , Moves Toward Florida Gulf Coast
message:
Tropical Storm Debby intensified into a Category 1 hurricane as it continues to move toward the Big Bend stretch of Florida's Gulf Coast ahead of expected landfall Monday (August 5) morning, CBS News reports.
Debby is the fourth named storm reported during Atlantic hurricane season, the National Hurricane Center announced on Saturday (August 3).
The agency predicted Debby would bring drenching rain and coastal flooding, which would begin Sunday (August 4) night.
"There is a danger of life-threatening storm surge along portions of the Gulf Coast of Florida, with 6 to 10 feet of inundation above ground level expected somewhere between Ochlockonee River to Yankeetown late tonight and Monday morning," the National Hurricane Center wrote at around 11:00 p.m.
"Residents in the Storm Surge Warning area should follow any advice given by local officials."
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Debby intensified into a Category 1 hurricane on Monday (August 5) morning and is expected to bring drenching rain and coastal flooding along Florida's Gulf Coast.

title: As storm Debby strengthens , US southeast braces for  historic  rainfall
message:
Debby grew rapidly into a Category One hurricane, the lowest on a five-stage scale, thanks to unusually warm Gulf of Mexico and is expected to slam into Florida's Big Bend region around mid-day Monday.
The storm will probably cause catastrophic flooding with "potentially historic heavy rainfall" when Debby moves northeast across Georgia and South Carolina over the next few days, the NHC said.
"We are looking at potentially really, really significant flooding that will happen, particularly in north-central Florida," Governor Ron DeSantis told an emergency briefing on the storm Sunday.
He and NHC deputy director Jamie Rhome have stressed that Floridians should be making and completing their final emergency preparations immediately.
President Joe Biden on Sunday approved an emergency declaration for Florida, allowing federal aid to be expedited.
event_breakdown:
1. Hurricane Debby is projected to slam into Florida's Big Bend region around mid-day Monday. 
2. Experts have warned of catastrophic flooding with potentially historic heavy rainfall when Debby moves northeast across Georgia and South Carolina over the next few days.

title: Hurricane Debby takes aim at Florida Gulf Coast , expected to slog up East Coast
message:
(Reuters) - Hurricane Debby is expected to slam into the Big Bend region of Florida's Gulf Coast by midday on Monday before slowly crossing the state, causing potentially dangerous storm surges and catastrophic flooding, the National Hurricane Center (NHC) said.
The hurricane center forecast life-threatening conditions, including storm surges up to 10 feet (3 meters) in some areas.
"This is going to be the story of this storm," said Jamie Rhome, the deputy director of the hurricane center.
The eye of Debby would move across the eastern Gulf of Mexico and reach the Florida Big Bend coast by midday on Monday, the hurricane center added.
Debby was then expected to move slowly across northern Florida and southern Georgia on Monday and Tuesday, it said.

title: Debby Intensifies Into Hurricane , Moves Toward Florida Gulf Coast
message:
Tropical Storm Debby intensified into a Category 1 hurricane as it continues to move toward the Big Bend stretch of Florida's Gulf Coast ahead of expected landfall Monday (August 5) morning, CBS News reports.
Debby is the fourth named storm reported during Atlantic hurricane season, the National Hurricane Center announced on Saturday (August 3).
The agency predicted Debby would bring drenching rain and coastal flooding, which would begin Sunday (August 4) night.
"There is a danger of life-threatening storm surge along portions of the Gulf Coast of Florida, with 6 to 10 feet of inundation above ground level expected somewhere between Ochlockonee River to Yankeetown late tonight and Monday morning," the National Hurricane Center wrote at around 11:00 p.m.
"Residents in the Storm Surge Warning area should follow any advice given by local officials."
event_breakdown:
1. Tropical Storm Debby intensified into a Category 1 hurricane as it continues to move toward the Big Bend stretch of Florida's Gulf Coast ahead of expected landfall Monday (August 5) morning, CBS News reports.
2. A multi-day ice storm has been slamming regions in Montana, leaving feet of snow and causing dangerous or even life-threatening travel conditions, according to local CBS affiliates.
3. New Orleans residents have a potential for a near-record-breaking heatwave this weekend, as a storm system could bring dangerous heat indexes to the southeastern United States.
4. A storm system that dumped several centimeters of rain on eastern Japan overnight has left at least 10 people dead and one missing, officials and news reports said today.
5. After an active severe weather day on Wednesday, another risk currently remains with a second potential wave of storms possible across a large portion of the central and southern Plains Friday night into Saturday, according to the National Weather Service.
6. Flash floods following heavy rainfall inundated southeast Tehran during August 4, 2018 and forced evacuation of inhabitants from nearby neighborhoods.

"Residents in the Storm Surge Warning area should follow any advice given by local officials."

title: Major flooding possible in SC as Hurricane Debby is forecast to drench Columbia area
message:
Major flooding possible in SC as Hurricane Debby is forecast to drench Columbia areaHurricane Debby made landfall in the U.S. on Monday, and will move north toward the Columbia area of South Carolina, where a flood watch has been issued, according to the National Weather Service.
A flood watch was issued in the Midlands as Hurricane Debby is forecast to bring excessive rain as it approaches from the south.
As of 5 a.m. Monday, the Hurricane Debby was moving northeast at 10 mph, and had maximum sustained winds of 75 mph, according to the National Hurricane Center.
Debby is expected to weaken as it moves over land Monday and through the night, according to the National Hurricane Center.
As of Sunday night, Debby’s winds are not expected to be a major threat to the Columbia area, the National Weather Service said.

The storm made landfall as a Category 1 storm near Steinhatchee, a tiny community in northern Florida of less than 1,000 residents on Florida’s Gulf Coast.
The storm made landfall in one of the least populated areas of Florida, but forecasters warned heavy rain could spawn catastrophic flooding in Florida, South Carolina and Georgia.
Hurricane Debby made landfall Monday morning in the Big Bend area of Florida.
Debby is the fourth named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season after Tropical Storm Alberto, Hurricane Beryl and Tropical Storm Chris, all of which formed in June.
The sparsely populated Big Bend region in the Florida Panhandle also was hit last year by Hurricane Idalia, which made landfall as a Category 3 hurricane.
event_breakdown:
1. On Monday, a tropical depression in the Gulf of Mexico strengthened into Tropical Storm Alberto as it moved towards the U.S. Gulf Coast.
2. The city of New Orleans is under a storm warning Friday morning, and the National Hurricane Center in Miami said it is possible that a tropical system could hit the city early next week.
3. Puerto Rico is bracing for another storm after Hurricane Maria caused widespread destruction when it made landfall as a Category 4 storm in September.
4. Hawaii is under a state of emergency as the state prepares for a potential storm.
5. Hurricanes are a type of storm that forms in the Atlantic Ocean.
6. Mexico is currently facing the effects of the Pacific "El Niño" phenomenon, which is characterized by increasingly severe storms and weather events.
7. At the end of November, the U.S. east coast wasn’t braced for another week’s worth of tornadoes, thunderstorms and, in some areas, flash flooding.
8. At the beginning of June, the Atlantic hurricane season officially started, and hurricane season has already been marked by the formation of four named storms.
9. Tropical Storm Alberto made landfall in Florida on Sunday.
10. The Gulf of Mexico is currently under a tropical storm warning. The tropical storm, Alberto, is currently located over the Gulf of Mexico and is moving in a northeasterly direction.”

title: Debby becomes Category 1 hurricane ahead of expected landfall in Florida
message:
The National Hurricane Center says Debby strengthened into a Category 1 hurricane on Sunday night, with a landfall expected in the Florida Big Bend area on Monday.
Hurricane Debby is expected to produce hurricane conditions on Monday in the Big Bend area where a hurricane warning is in effect, but tropical storm conditions began Sunday evening.
A hurricane warning is in effect for the Florida coast from the Suwannee River to Indian Pass, along with the Valdosta area in south Georgia.
A hurricane watch is in effect for the Florida coast south of the Suwannee River to Yankeetown.
Hurricane Debby is expected to bring heavy rainfall as well as flash and urban flooding to portions of northern Florida.

title: Hurricane Debby makes landfall in Florida with 99 - mph wind gusts and a 6 - foot storm surge
message:
Hurricane Debby made landfall as a Category 1 hurricane just before 7:00 a.m. EDT Monday morning near Steinhatchee along Florida's Big Bend.
The landfall is within 20 miles of Hurricane Idalia's landfall, a Category 3 storm that roared ashore in the Big Bend of Florida in August 2023.
Up to 6 feet of storm surge flooding occurred at Cedar Key early Monday morning.
On Sunday, a significant overwash occurred in St. Petersburg, Florida, as a 4-foot storm surge hit Tampa Bay.
AccuWeather meteorologists warn that Debby could stall along the Carolina coast this week, which may significantly exacerbate the life-threatening conditions.

message:

title: Debby morphs into a hurricane , landfall expected in Florida | Hurricane Wire
message:
Tropical Storm Debby strengthened into a Category 1 hurricane over the northeast Gulf of Mexico and made landfall around 7 a.m. in the Big Bend region of Florida.
From there, Debby will likely follow a northeast track over Florida and into Georgia and South Carolina.
Tropical storm and storm surge warnings are posted along the coast of South Carolina.
It's predicted to lose some strength as it moves over land, reverting to a tropical storm.
The region from Savannah to Charleston could see as much as 30 inches of rain over the next five days.

Tropical Storm Debby strengthens into a hurricane, hits Florida
June 23, 2022: As of today, a tropical storm has strengthened into a hurricane over the northeast Gulf of Mexico, having made landfall in the Big Bend region of Florida.
From there Debby will likely follow a northeast track along Florida, over Georgia and into South Carolina. A tropical storm and storm surge warning are in effect along the coast of South Carolina. As Debby moves into land it is expected to weaken and become once more a tropical storm.
The region from Savannah to Charleston could see up to 30 inches of rain over the next 5 days.

message:

Key local and state agencies have been notified to be ready to respond if the need arises, SCEMD officials announced Monday.
Our experts with the National Hurricane Center believe flooding to be catastrophic for many parts of South Carolina.

title: Hurricane Debby roars ashore in Florida
message:
At least one person was killed as Tropical Storm Debby began dumping what could become historic levels of rain over Florida Monday, with the southeastern United States braced for potentially "catastrophic" flooding.
Authorities say the danger remains high as the storm moves over the state and into Georgia and South Carolina, despite the downgrade by the National Hurricane Center.
"This is going to result in a prolonged extreme rainfall event with potential for catastrophic flooding across coastal portions of Georgia, South Carolina, even extending up into North Carolina," he said.
Florida governor Ron DeSantis also warned of "significant" flooding over the coming days, and said the state had already seen storm surge and some water rising.
The storm will probably cause catastrophic flooding with "potentially historic heavy rainfall" when Debby moves northeast across Georgia and South Carolina over the next few days, the NHC said.

title: Hurricane Slams Florida After Gaining Fury in Warm Waters
message:
Hurricane Debby slammed into Florida southeast of Tallahassee as a Category 1 storm after intensifying over warm waters, the latest evidence that this will be a robust season for tropical cyclones.
Months of record warm water across the Atlantic has raised alarm that 2024 would be a very hurricane active season.
Debby is already the second storm to make landfall in the US this year following Beryl, which struck eastern Texas last month and caused a massive power outage.
A year ago, Hurricane Idalia made landfall in the Big Bend area as a Category 3 hurricane.

title: Hurricane Debby could bring heavy rain to much of NC this week . Here when and where .
message:
Hurricane Debby could bring heavy rain to much of NC this week.
Debby will move offshore from Georgia or South Carolina into the Atlantic on Thursday morning, forecasters say, before making landfall again in South Carolina sometime Friday.
From there it’s expected to move north into North Carolina, still a tropical storm.
Flash flooding is possible in all but extreme western North Carolina this week as what becomes Tropical Storm Debby moves slowly over the Southeast.
Along the coast, dangerous storm surge and wind impacts are expected from Florida all the way to North Carolina through midweek.

title: Week of extreme rains expected after Debby slams Florida coast
message:
The storm had lost some of its windspeed after slamming Florida's Gulf Coast around 7 a.m. on Monday morning as a Category 1 hurricane.
It made landfall near Steinhatchee, in the Big Bend region about 70 miles (115 km) southeast of Tallahassee, delivering winds of up to 80 mph (130 kph), the National Hurricane Center said.
The hurricane center predicted Debby would move offshore into the Atlantic by Tuesday night, then re-strengthen and come back inland to drench the coasts of Georgia and South Carolina later in the week.
The governors of Georgia and South Carolina have declared states of emergency in anticipation of Debby's damage.
By midday Monday, Debby had already dumped eight to 16 inches of rain in some parts of central Florida, according to local weather reports.

title: Tropical Storm Debby Hits Florida With Floods , Threat Of Record Rain In Georgia And The Carolinas
message:
Tropical Storm Debby slammed Florida with catastrophic flooding and was blamed for at least four deaths, with Georgia and South Carolina next in line as the system rips across the southeastern United States.
Debby made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane over the gulf coast of Florida.
Vice President Kamala Harris has postponed a scheduled trip to Georgia amid the ongoing effects of Tropical Storm Debby.
In South Carolina, Charleston County Interim Emergency Director Ben Webster called Debby a “historic and potentially unprecedented event” three times in a 90-second briefing Monday morning.
North Carolina and South Carolina have dealt with three catastrophic floods from tropical systems in the past nine years, all causing more than $1 billion in damage.

title: Catfish in driveway  as Hurricane Debby slams Florida ; video
message:
A St. Petersburg, Fla., resident on Sunday shared footage showing catfish floundering in his yard during extensive flooding caused by Hurricane Debby.
“Catfish in my driveway as streets turn into rivers!” Dan Ciarletta described via X.
As of Monday morning, Hurricane Debby hade made landfall along the Gulf Coast and was causing extensive flooding that seemed to flush fish from area waterways.
Ciarletta posted two videos showing catfish wriggling in shallow water outside his home.
Ciarletta assumed that the catfish were flushed onto his neighborhood streets via flooded storm drains.

title: Tropical Storm Debby blew $1 million worth of cocaine onto Florida Keys beach , Border Patrol says
message:
Tropical Storm Debby blew $1 million worth of cocaine onto Florida Keys beach, Border Patrol saysAs thousands of Floridians braced for the impact of Tropical Storm Debby on Monday, Border Patrol seized dozens of packages of cocaine.
The storm's outer skirt brought high winds and storms to the Florida Keys Monday morning.
Authorities received a call from a Good Samaritan saying he found drug packages on a Florida Keys beach.
Border Patrol officers seized 70 pounds of cocaine on the beach that had blown out by Tropical Storm Debby.

Tropical Storm Alex:

Tropical Storm Alex formed in the Atlantic Ocean on Sunday, the US National Hurricane Center said, threatening areas of Florida already reeling with heavy rain and Covid-19 cases. 

The Miami-based US National Hurricane Center (NHC) upgraded the tropical depression that formed earlier in the day about 275 miles (440 kilometers) off the southern tip of Florida to Tropical Storm Alex, packing maximum sustained winds of 40 miles per hour.

"Flash flood watches are in effect for much of southern Florida, including Miami, Fort Lauderdale and West Palm Beach," said the NHC. "Heavy rainfall was still expected to continue across South Florida through at least mid week."

Alex was expected to become a hurricane by Monday as it moves north, though no coastal watches or warnings were in effect.

Miami-Dade and Broward counties, which are among Florida to have recently reported the highest numbers of coronavirus infections, are under heat advisories through at least Tuesday with heat index predicted between 105 and 110 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: Horry County moves to OPCON2 in preparation for Debby
message:
Horry County moved to OPCON2 Monday ahead of Hurricane Debby's arrival in the Carolinas.
The move means the county is operating in a "heightened state of awareness with emergency plans beginning to be implemented."
The Horry County Emergency Operations Center is not currently activated, however, action will be taken as necessary.
READ MORE:In anticipation of possible impacts, Horry Emergency Management reminds all residents to prepare by:Surveying your property to mitigate potential flooding, such as making sure storm drains and gutters are clear of debris.
For the latest Debby update from the ABC15 Weather Authority Team,
event_breakdown: Horry County moved to OPCON2 Monday ahead of Hurricane Debby's arrival in the Carolinas. Horry County Emergency Management reminds residents to prepare by: surveying their property to mitigate potential flooding, such as making sure storm drains and gutters are clear of debris. Residents should also identify and secure loose items in their yards and exteriors of their homes; bring all outside furniture, decorations, and potted plants inside or tie them down securely.

title: Weather Evacuations : Tropical Storm Debby to Become Hurricane , Make Florida Landfall by Monday
message:
Tropical Storm Debby could be upgraded to hurricane status by Monday as it heads toward Florida from the Gulf of Mexico, weather officials have predicted.
Portions of Southwest Florida are already feeling the storm’s impact even before it makes it to land, with officials issuing tornado warnings, watches, and evacuations as the wind and rainfall pick up, FOX Weather reported.
According to the National Hurricane Center (NHC), there is danger of a “life-threatening storm surge” along parts of Florida’s Gulf Coast, with six to ten feet of flooding expected between the Ochlockonee and Suwanee Rivers.
“You have a few more hours to get to a safe place before conditions begin to deteriorate by this evening,” Brennan warned, before explaining that Debby is set to flood other parts of the southeastern U.S. after Florida.
The NHC is “especially concerned” about the area from Savannah, Georgia, and up through Charleston, South Carolina, to Myrtle Beach due to “excessive rainfall,” the weather expert added.

title: Hurricane Debby makes landfall in northern Florida as Category 1 storm – Times News Online
message:
TAMPA, Fla. (AP) — Hurricane Debby has made landfall Monday in northern Florida as a Category 1 storm.
The storm made landfall in one of the least populated areas of Florida, but forecasters warned heavy rain could spawn catastrophic flooding in Florida, South Carolina and Georgia.
The sparsely populated Big Bend region in the Florida Panhandle also was hit last year by Hurricane Idalia, which made landfall as a Category 3 hurricane.
Debby is the fourth named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season after Tropical Storm Alberto, Hurricane Beryl and Tropical Storm Chris, all of which formed in June.
Floodwaters cover parts of the Shore Acres neighborhood of St. Petersburg, Fla., as a result of Tropical Storm Debby Sunday afternoon, Aug. 4, 2024.

title: Tropical Storm Debby strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane as it heads toward Florida – Brandon Sun
message:
TAMPA, Fla. (AP) — Tropical Storm Debby strengthened into a Category 1 hurricane as it approached Florida on Sunday evening, according to the national weather service.
Debby is the fourth named storm of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season after Tropical Storm Alberto, Hurricane Beryl and Tropical Storm Chris, all of which formed in June.
Forecasters warned heavy amounts of rain from Debby could spawn catastrophic flooding in Florida, South Carolina and Georgia.
A tropical storm watch extended farther west into the Panhandle.
We’re doing everything that we need to be prepared to face a tropical storm,” Tampa Mayor Jane Castor said.
